aboveboard.example: The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard -- some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get away with it.

abysmal.example: Coach Ramsey took his newest player off the field after watching a few painful minutes of her abysmal performance.

acme.example: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.

advocate.example: While the senator privately approved of gay marriage, he was unwilling to advocate for the cause in a public venue.
advocate.meaning: speak, plead, or argue in favor of
advocate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

advocate.example: Martin Luther King Jr. was a tireless advocate for the rights of African-Americans in the United States.
advocate.meaning: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
advocate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

affable.example: For all his surface affability, Marco was remarkably glum when he wasn't around other people.

affluent.example: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.

altruism.example: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.
altruism.meaning: the quality of unselfish concern for the welfare of others

amiable.example: Amy's name was very apt: she was so amiable that she was twice voted class president.

amply.example: The boat was amply supplied for its year at sea--no man would go hungry or thirst.

amuck.example: Wherever the bowl haircut teen-idol went, his legions of screaming fans ran through the streets amuck, hoping for a glance at his boyish face.
amuck.meaning: in a frenzied or uncontrolled state

analogous.example: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.
analogous.meaning: similar in some respects but otherwise different

animosity.example: The governor's animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor's first term.

antedated.example: Harry was so unknowledgable that he was unaware the Egyptian pharaohs antedated the American Revolution.

antiquated.example: Aunt Betty had antiquated notions about marriage, believing that a man should court a woman for at least a year before receiving a kiss.
antiquated.meaning: old-fashioned; belonging to an earlier period in time

apex.example: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the secondary education system.

aphorism.example: Nietzsche was known for using aphorisms, sometimes encapsulating a complex philosophical thought in a mere sentence.
aphorism.meaning: a short instructive saying about a general truth

aphoristic.example: Sometimes I can't stand Nathan because he tries to impress everyone by being aphoristic, but he just states the obvious.
aphoristic.meaning: something that is a concise and instructive of a general truth or principle

appreciable.example: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.
appreciable.meaning: large enough to be noticed (usu. refers to an amount)

apprehension.example: Test day can be one of pure apprehension, as many students worry about their test scores.

archaic.example: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice--needless to say, she didn't have many friends.
archaic.meaning: so old as to appear to belong to a different period

ascendancy.example: The ascendancy of the Carlsbad water polo team is clear--they have a decade of championships behind them.
ascendancy.meaning: the state that exists when one person or group has power over another

ascribe.example: History ascribes The Odyssey and The Illiad to Homer, but scholars now debate whether he was a historical figure or a fictitious name.

assail.example: In the weekly paper, the editor assailed the governor for wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in public projects that quickly failed.

assuage.example: Her fear that the new college would be filled with unknown faces was assuaged when she recognized her childhood friend standing in line.

augment.example: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.

autonomously.example: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.
autonomously.meaning: In an autonomous or self-governing manner.

avarice.example: The Spanish conquistadors were known for their avarice, plundering Incan land and stealing Incan gold.
avarice.meaning: greed (one of the seven deadly sins)

avert.example: Afraid to see the aftermath of the car crash, I averted my eyes as we drove by.
The struggling videogame company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankrupcy.

avid.example: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.
avid.meaning: marked by active interest and enthusiasm

badger.example: Badgered by his parents to find a job, the 30-year-old loafer instead joined a gang of itinerant musicians.
badger.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

balk.example: The students were willing to clean up the broken glass, but when the teacher asked them to mop the entire floor, they balked, citing reasons why they needed to leave.

banish.example: The most difficult part of the fast was banishing thoughts of food.
banish.meaning: expel from a community, residence, or location; drive away
banish.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

beatific.example: Often we imagine all monks to wear the beatific smile of the Buddha, but, like any of us, a monk can have a bad day and not look very happy.

becoming.example: Her dress was becoming and made her look even more beautiful.
becoming.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

begrudge.example: Sitting all alone in his room, Harvey begrudged the happiness of the other children playing outside his window.
begrudge.meaning: to envy someone for possessing or enjoying something

begrudge.example: We never begrudge money spent on ourselves.

behoove.example: The teacher looked down at the student and said, "It would behoove you to be in class on time and complete your homework, so that you don't repeat freshman English for a third straight year."
behoove.meaning: to be one's duty or obligation

belittle.example: A good teacher will never belittle his students, but will instead empower them.
belittle.meaning: lessen the importance, dignity, or reputation of

bellicose.example: Known for their bellicose ways, the Spartans were once the most feared people from Peloponnesus to Persia.

benign.example: I remember my grandfather's face was wrinkled, benign, and calm.
The tumor located in your ear lobe seems to be benign and should not cause you any trouble.
benign.meaning: (medicine) not dangerous to health; not recurrent or progressive

besiege.example: After discovering a priceless artifact in her backyard, Jane was besieged by phone calls, emails, and reporters all trying to buy, hold or see the rare piece of history.
besiege.meaning: harass, as with questions or requests; cause to feel distressed or worried

besmirch.example: The prince's distasteful choice of words besmirched not only his own name, but the reputation of the entire royal family.
besmirch.meaning: damage the good name and reputation of someone

bleak.example: Unremitting overcast skies tend to lead people to create bleak literature and lugubrious music -compare England's band Radiohead to any band from Southern California.
bleak.meaning: having a depressing or gloomy outlook

boon.example: Modern technology has been a boon to the travel industry.
He was a boon companion to many, and will be sadly missed.

boorish.example: Bukowski was known for being a boorish drunk and alienating close friends and family.
boorish.meaning: ill-mannered and coarse or contemptible in behavior or appearance

brusquely.example: Not one for social pleasantries, the Chief of Staff would brusquely ask his subordinates anything he wanted, even coffee.

buck.example: The profits at our firm bucked the general downturn that effected the real estate industry.
buck.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

buttress.example: China's economy has been buttressed by a global demand for the electronic parts the country manufactures.

cadaverous.example: Some actors take challenging roles in which they have to lose so much weight that they appear cadaverous.

candid.example: Even with a perfect stranger, Charles was always candid and would rarely hold anything back.
candid.meaning: a straightforward and honest look at something

candidness.example: Although I was unhappy that the relationship ended, I appreciated her candidness about why she was ready to move on from the relationship.
candidness.meaning: the quality of being honest and straightforward in attitude and speech

cardinal.example: Most cultures consider gambling a cardinal sin and thus have outlawed its practice.
cardinal.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

carping.example: What seemed like incessant nagging and carping about my behavior from my mother turned out to be wise and useful advice that has served me well.

catalyst.example: Rosa Park's refusal to give up her bus seat acted as a catalyst for the Civil Rights Movement, setting into motion historic changes for African-Americans.
catalyst.meaning: something that speeds up an event

cavalier.example: Percy dismissed the issue with a cavalier wave of his hand.
cavalier.meaning: given to haughty disregard of others

censor.example: Every fall, high school English teachers are inundated by requests to censor their curriculum by removing The Catcher in the Rye and Scarlet Letter from their reading lists.
censor.meaning: to examine and remove objectionable material

cerebral.example: A cerebral analysis of most pop music finds it to be simple and childish, but that ignores the point--the music's effect on the listener.
cerebral.meaning: involving intelligence rather than emotions or instinct
cerebral.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

champion.example: Martin Luther King Jr. championed civil rights fiercely throughout his short life.
champion.meaning: protect or fight for as a champion
champion.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

chauvinist.example: The chauvinist lives on both sides of the political spectrum, outright shunning anybody whose ideas are not consistent with his own.
chauvinist.meaning: a person who believes in the superiority of their group

check.example: Deserted for six months, the property began to look more like a jungle and less like a residence--weeds grew unchecked in the front yard
check.meaning: to limit (usually modifying the growth of something)
check.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

check.example: When government abuses are not kept in check, that government is likely to become autocratic.
check.meaning: the condition of being held back or limited
check.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

checkered.example: One by one, the presidential candidates dropped out of the race, their respective checkered pasts-- from embezzlement to infidelity--sabotaging their campaigns.
checkered.meaning: one that is marked by disreputable happenings
checkered.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

chivalrous.example: Marco's chivalrous ways, like opening doors and pulling out chairs, was much appreciated by his date.
chivalrous.meaning: being attentive to women like an ideal knight

clemency.example: administering justice In the final moments of the trial, during his closing speech, Phillips was nearly begging the judge for clemency.
clemency.meaning: leniency and compassion shown toward offenders by a person or agency charged with

coalesce.example: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.
coalesce.meaning: fuse or cause to grow together

cogent.example: A cogent argument will change the minds of even the most skeptical audience.

cohesive.example: A well-written, cohesive essay will keep on topic at all times, never losing sight of the main argument.
cohesive.meaning: well integrated, forming a united whole

collusion.example: Many have argued that Lee Harvey Oswald, JFK's assassin, was in collusion with other criminals; others maintain that Oswald was a lone gunman.

colossal.example: Few appreciate the colossal scale of the sun: if hollow, it could contain a million Earths.
colossal.meaning: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

commendable.example: The efforts of the firefighters running into the burning building were commendable.

complacent.example: After the water polo team won their sixth championship, they became complacent and didn't even make it to the playoffs the next year.
complacent.meaning: contented to a fault with oneself or one's actions

complementary.example: The head waiter was careful to tell the amateur diners that red wine was complementary with beef, each bringing out subtle taste notes in the other.
complementary.meaning: enhancing each other's qualities (for two things or more).

compound.example: Her headache was compounded by the construction crew outside, which had six jackhammers going at the same time.
compound.meaning: make more intense, stronger, or more marked
compound.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

conducive.example: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.
conducive.meaning: making a situation or outcome more likely to happen

conniving.example: The queen was so conniving that, with the help of the prince, she tried to overthrow the king.
conniving.meaning: taking part in immoral and unethical plots

consecrate.example: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.
consecrate.meaning: to make holy or set apart for a high purpose

constraint.example: He found pop music a constraint on his ability to learn and preferred to listen to classical musical while studying.

consummate.example: Tyler was the consummate musician: he was able to play the guitar, harmonica, and the drum at the same time.
consummate.meaning: having or revealing supreme mastery or skill
consummate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

consummate.example: The restoration of the ancient church was only consummated after a twenty years of labor.
consummate.meaning: to make perfect and complete in every respect
consummate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

contemptuous.example: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.
contemptuous.meaning: scornful, looking down at others with a sneering attitude

contrite.example: Though he stole his little sister's licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn't stop crying.

conundrum.example: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.

convivial.example: The wedding reception was convivial; friends who hadn't seen each other for ages drank and ate together before heading to the dance floor.

convoluted.example: Instead of solving the math problem in three simple steps, Kumar used a convoluted solution requiring fifteen steps.

cornucopia.example: The International Food Expo was a cornucopia of culinary delights: gourmet foods from every continent were under one roof.
cornucopia.meaning: an abundant supply of something good

corroborate.example: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.
corroborate.meaning: to confirm or lend support to (usually an idea or claim)

cosmopolitan.example: There are few cities in the world as diverse and cosmopolitan as New York.
cosmopolitan.meaning: comprising many cultures; global in reach and outlook

credence.example: He placed no credence in psychics, claiming that they offered no special powers beyond the ability to make people part with their money.

creditable.example: Critics agreed the movie was creditable, but few gave it more than three out of five stars.
creditable.meaning: deserving of praise but not that amazing

credulity.example: Virginia's wide-eyed credulity as a five-year old was replaced by suspicion after she learned that Santa Claus didn't really exist.

cumbersome.example: Only ten years ago, being an avid reader and a traveler meant carrying a cumbersome backpack stuffed with books--these days we need only an e-reader.
cumbersome.meaning: difficult to handle or use especially because of size or weight

dearth.example: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.

debase.example: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.
debase.meaning: reduce the quality or value of something

debunk.example: Richard Dawkins tries to debunk religious belief, but his ridicule tends to push people away from his points rather than convince them.
debunk.meaning: expose as false ideas and claims, especially while ridiculing

decimation.example: The decimation after atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki is incomprehensible.
decimation.meaning: destroying or killing a large part of the population

degrade.example: Jesse had mockingly pointed out all of Nancy's faults in front of their friends, publicly degrading the poor girl.
degrade.meaning: reduce in worth or character, usually verbally

delegate.example: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.
delegate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

deliberate.example: Emergency situations such as this call for immediate action and leave no room to deliberate over options.
deliberate.meaning: think about carefully; weigh the pros and cons of an issue
deliberate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

demean.example: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.
demean.meaning: to insult; to cause someone to lose dignity or respect

demure.example: The portrait of her in a simple white blouse was sweet and demure.

deride.example: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.
deride.meaning: treat or speak of with contempt

derisive.example: I was surprised by her derisive tone; usually, she is sweet, soft spoken, and congenial.
derisive.meaning: abusing vocally; expressing contempt or ridicule

derogative.example: Never before have we seen a debate between two political candidates that was so derogative and filthy.
derogative.meaning: expressed as worthless or in negative terms

desecrate.example: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.
desecrate.meaning: to willfully violate or destroy a sacred place

destitute.example: Jean Valjean, is at first destitute, but through the grace of a priest, he makes something of his life.
destitute.meaning: poor enough to need help from others

destitute.example: Now that the mine is closed, the town is destitute of any economic activity.

deter.example: His mother tried to deter him from joing the army, but he was too intoxicated with the idea of war to listen.
The government's primary job should invlove deterring paths to war, not finding ways to start them.
deter.meaning: try to prevent; show opposition to

detrimental.example: Many know that smoking is detrimental to your health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.
detrimental.meaning: (sometimes followed by "to") causing harm or injury

devolve.example: The company was full of managers known for devolving tasks to lower management, but never doing much work themselves.
devolve.meaning: pass on or delegate to another

devolve.example: The dialogue between the two academics devolved into a downright bitter argument.

diabolical.example: The conspirators, willing to dispatch anyone who stood in their way, hatched a diabolical plan to take over the city.
diabolical.meaning: to be extremely wicked like the devil

differentiate.example: Mozart's long melodic lines differentiate his compositions from other works of late 18th century music.
differentiate.meaning: be a distinctive feature, attribute, or trait (sometimes in positive sense)

differentiate.example: environment Animals on Madagascar differentiated from other similar animal species due to many years of isolation on the island.
differentiate.meaning: evolve so as to lead to a new species or develop in a way most suited to the

dilapidated.example: The main house has been restored but the gazebo is still dilapidated and unuseable.

diligent.example: Michael was a diligent gardener, never leaving a leaf on the ground and regularly watering each plant.
diligent.meaning: characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks

discord.example: Despite all their talented players, the team was filled with discord--some players refused to talk to others--and lost most of their games.

discreet.example: advantage The professor thought that he was discreet, subtly wiping the stain off of his shirt, but as soon as he stepped off the podium a member of the audience pointed out the large ketchup stain.
discreet.meaning: careful to protect one's speech or actions in order to avoid offense or gain an

discriminate.example: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.
discriminate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

disenfranchise.example: The U.S. Constitution disenfranchised women until 1920 when they were given the right to vote.

disheartened.example: After the visiting team scored nine times, the home team's fans were disheartened, some leaving the game early.

disparate.example: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.

dispatch.example: She finished her thesis with dispatch, amazing her advisors who couldn't believe she hadn't written 60 scholarly pages so quickly.
dispatch.meaning: the property of being prompt and efficient
dispatch.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

dispatch.example: As soon as the angry peasants stormed the castle, they caught the king and swiftly dispatched him.
dispatch.meaning: dispose of rapidly and without delay and efficiently
dispatch.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

docile.example: Barnyard animals are considerably more docile than the wild animals.
docile.meaning: easily handled or managed; willing to be taught or led or supervised or directed

dog.example: Throughout his life, he was dogged by insecurities that inhibited personal growth.
dog.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

dupe.example: Once again a get-rich-fast Internt scheme had duped Harold into submitting a $5,000 check to a sham operation.
The charlatan mistook the crowd for a bunch of dupes, but the crowd was quickly on to him and decried his bald-faced attempt to bilk them.
dupe.meaning: a person who is easily tricked or swindled

eccentric.example: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.
eccentric.meaning: highly unconventional or usual (usually describes a person)

egotist.example: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.

eke.example: Stranded in a cabin over the winter, Terry was able to eke out an existence on canned food.
eke.meaning: To live off meager resources, to scrape by

elaborate.example: Thomas, on returning from Morocco, replaced his dirty gray carpet with an elaborate one he'd brought back with him.
elaborate.meaning: marked by complexity and richness of detail

elaborate.example: Most high school physics teachers find themselves elaborating the same point over and over again, since many concepts confuse students.

elude.example: Even a basic understanding of physics can elude most high schools students.

elusive.example: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive.
elusive.meaning: difficult to capture or difficult to remember

embellish.example: McCartney would write relatively straightforward lyrics, and Lennon would embellish them with puns and poetic images.
embellish.meaning: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.; make more beautiful

embroiled.example: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal--a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can sink their teeth into a fresh one.

empathetic.example: emotions Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspitations and fears.
empathetic.meaning: showing understanding and ready comprehension of other peoples' states and

emulate.example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.
emulate.meaning: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating; compete with successfully

endemic.example: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.
endemic.meaning: native; originating where it is found

enmity.example: Charles rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

entice.example: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.
entice.meaning: get someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises

enumerate.example: The survey enumerates the number of happy workers and the number of unhappy workers.
enumerate.meaning: determine the number or amount of

enumerate.example: I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.

err.example: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

errant.example: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.
errant.meaning: to be wandering; not sticking to a circumscribed path

erratic.example: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President's attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.

euphoria.example: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.
euphoria.meaning: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation

evasive.example: His responses were clearly evasive; he obviously did not want to take on any responsibility or any new work.
evasive.meaning: avoiding or escaping from difficulty or danger or commitment

evasive.example: Every time I call the bank, I receive the same evasive answers about our mortgage and never get a clear response.

evenhanded.example: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

exasperate.example: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.

excruciating.example: After the boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.

exemplify.example: Lincoln exemplified the best of not only America, but also the potential greatness that exists within each person.
Please present some case studies that exemplify the results that you claim in your paper.
exemplify.meaning: clarify by giving an example of

exhort.example: Nelson's parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

extenuating.example: The jury was hardly moved by the man's plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.
extenuating.meaning: making less guilty or more forgivable

facetious.example: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex eduation class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.

fawn.example: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.
fawn.meaning: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ferret.example: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.
ferret.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

fete.example: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

fickle.example: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.
fickle.meaning: liable to sudden unpredictable change, esp. in affections or attachments

finagle.example: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.
finagle.meaning: achieve something by means of trickery or devious methods

fledgling.example: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.
fledgling.meaning: young and inexperienced; describing any new participant in some activity

fleece.example: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.
fleece.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

flounder.example: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she has deal with taxes, she flounders.

flush.example: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

foible.example: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.
foible.meaning: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual

foolhardy.example: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear his bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.
foolhardy.meaning: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences

forthright.example: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasent surprised by how forthright he was.
forthright.meaning: characterized by directness in manner or speech; without subtlety or evasion

futile.example: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.
futile.meaning: producing no result or effect; unproductive of success

genial.example: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

genteel.example: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.
genteel.meaning: marked by refinement in taste and manners

glean.example: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.

glib.example: I have found that the more glib the salesman, the worse the product.
glib.meaning: (of a person) speaking with ease but without sincerity

goad.example: Doug did not want to enter the race, but Jim, through a steady stream of taunts, goaded him into signing up for it.

grovel.example: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire.

guffaw.example: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

hamper.example: As the rain water began to collect in pools on the highway, it began to hamper the flow of traffic.
hamper.meaning: prevent the progress or free movement of
hamper.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

hamstrung.example: The FBI has made so many restriction on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

heyday.example: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.
heyday.meaning: the pinnacle or top of a time period or career

hodgepodge.example: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of the city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

hound.example: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms--he even helped nab Al Capone.
hound.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

humdrum.example: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York City after moving.

illicit.example: Though Al Capone was engaged in many illicit activities, he was finally arrested for income tax evasion, a relatively minor offense.
illicit.meaning: contrary to or forbidden by law

immaterial.example: The judge found the defendant's comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

impeccable.example: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

impede.example: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.
impede.meaning: be a hindrance or obstacle to

impending.example: The impending doom of our world has been a discussed and debated for 2000 years--maybe even longer.
impending.meaning: close in time; about to occur

impermeable.example: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.
impermeable.meaning: does not allow fluids to pass through

implicate.example: By saying that some of the guests were uncomfortable, the manager implicated to the hotel staff that it needed to be more dilligent.
The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.
implicate.meaning: to indicate in wrongdoing, usually a crime

imponderable.example: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient healthcare system an imponderable task.
imponderable.meaning: impossible to estimate or figure out

impregnable.example: As a child, Amy would build pillow castles and pretend they were impregnable fotresses.
impregnable.meaning: immune to attack; incapable of being tampered with

inadvertent.example: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led its the repeal.
inadvertent.meaning: happening by chance or unexpectedly or unintentionally

inarticulate.example: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Black was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.
inarticulate.meaning: without or deprived of the use of speech or words

incense.example: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.
incense.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

incessant.example: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.
incessant.meaning: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing

inclement.example: After a week of inclement weather, we finally are able to go outside and enjoy the sun.
Marcus Aurelius, though a fair man, was inclement to Christians during his reign, persecuting them violently.
inclement.meaning: used of persons or behavior; showing no mercy

incumbent.example: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.
incumbent.meaning: necessary (for someone) as a duty or responsibility

indict.example: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.
indict.meaning: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing

indigenous.example: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S-one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you're not dealing with an opossum.

indignant.example: When the cyclist swerved into traffic, it forced the driver to brake and elicited an indignant shout of "Hey, punk, watch where you're going!"
indignant.meaning: feeling anger over a perceived injustice

industrious.example: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.
industrious.meaning: characterized by hard work and perseverance

inflammable.example: It only takes one person to leave an inflammable comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.

ingenuity.example: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.

inkling.example: Lynne speaks four Romance languages, but she doesn't have an inkling about how East Asian languages are structured.
inkling.meaning: a slight suggestion or vague understanding

insipid.example: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

insolvent.example: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.
insolvent.meaning: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt

intermittent.example: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning--a surreal sleepless night.
intermittent.meaning: stopping and starting at irregular intervals

inundate.example: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.

irascible.example: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becames highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

irk.example: My little sister has a way of irking and annoying me like no other person.

irresolute.example: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to the camp.
irresolute.meaning: uncertain how to act or proceed

jargon.example: To those with little training in medicine, the jargon of doctors can be very difficult to understand.
jargon.meaning: a characteristic language of a particular group

jocular.example: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knockknock jokes to anyone who would listen.
jocular.meaning: characterized by jokes and good humor

junta.example: As dangerous of a threat as North Korea is, some analysts believe that were a junta suddenly to gain power, it could be even more unpredictable and bellicose than the current leadership
junta.meaning: an aggressive takeover by a group (usually military)

laborious.example: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in King Salmon, Alaska.
laborious.meaning: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion; especially physical effort

leery.example: Without checking his references and talking to previous employers, I am leery of hiring the candidate.
leery.meaning: openly distrustful and unwilling to confide

lethargic.example: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

lucid.example: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

macabre.example: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of the macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to--and often those moments after--a grisly death.
macabre.meaning: suggesting the horror of death and decay; gruesome

malady.example: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

malevolent.example: Villians are known for their malevolent nature, oftentimes inflicting cruetly on others just for enjoyment.
malevolent.meaning: wishing or appearing to wish evil to others; arising from intense ill will or hatred

malleable.example: The clay became malleable and easy to work with after a little water was added.
malleable.meaning: capable of being shaped or bent or drawn out

malleable.example: My little brother is so malleable that I can convince him to sneak cookies from the cupboard for me.

malodorous.example: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes--the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

martial.example: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

maxim.example: Johnson initially suggests that the secret to business can be summarized in a single maxim but then requires a 300-page book to explain exactly what he means.
maxim.meaning: a short saying expressing a general truth

meander.example: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

melancholy.example: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

melee.example: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.
melee.meaning: a wild, confusing fight or struggle

mesmerize.example: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

misanthrope.example: Hamilton had been deceived so many times in his life that he hid behind the gruff exterior of a misanthrope, lambasting perfect strangers for no apparent reason.

miscreant.example: Come back you miscreant! yelled the woman who just had her purse stollen.
miscreant.meaning: a person who breaks the law

miser.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.
miser.meaning: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because they are greedy)

misogynist.example: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.
misogynist.meaning: a person who dislikes women in particular

moment.example: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton's writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.
moment.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

moot.example: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, what the finance committe might have thought of his proposed marketing plan for next year is now a moot point.
moot.meaning: open to argument or debate; undecidable in a meaningless or irrelevant way
moot.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

morose.example: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.
morose.meaning: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy

morph.example: The earnestness of the daytime talk shows of the 1970's has morphed into something far more sensational and vulgar: today guests actually standup and threaten to take swings at one another.
morph.meaning: To undergo dramatic change in a seamless and barely noticeable fashion.

muted.example: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.
muted.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obdurate.example: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.
obdurate.meaning: stubbornly persistent in changing an opinion or action

obliging.example: Even after all his success, I found him to be accommodating and obliging, sharing with me his "secret tips" on how to gain wealth and make friends.
obliging.meaning: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others

obstinate.example: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.
obstinate.meaning: resistant to guidance or discipline; stubbornly persistent

ornate.example: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.
ornate.meaning: marked by elaborate rhetoric and elaborated with decorative details

paradoxical.example: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.
paradoxical.meaning: seemingly contradictory but nonetheless possibly true

pastoral.example: Those who imagine America's countryside as a pastoral region are often disappointed to learn that much of rural U.S. is filled with cornfields extending as far as the eye can see.
pastoral.meaning: relating to the countryside in a pleasant sense

patronize.example: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.
patronize.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

paucity.example: There is a paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most jobs have either been automated or outsourced.

peevish.example: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping not to set off another one of his fits.

perennial.example: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.
perennial.meaning: lasting an indefinitely long time; eternal; everlasting
perennial.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

perpetuate.example: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

perquisite.example: official right) Even as the dishwasher at the French restaurant, Josh quickly learned that he had the perquisite of being able to eat terrific food for half the price diners would pay.
perquisite.meaning: a right reserved exclusively by a particular person or group (especially a hereditary or

pertinent.example: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays the best on the field.
pertinent.meaning: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand

perturb.example: Now that Henry is recovering from a major illnesses, he no longer lets the little trivialities, such as late mail, perturb him.
perturb.meaning: disturb in mind or cause to be worried or alarmed

peruse.example: Instead of perusing important documents, people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures at the bottom.

pine.example: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.
pine.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pinnacle.example: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

piquant.example: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.

pithy.example: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.

pittance.example: Vinny's uncle beamed smugly about how he'd offered his nephew fifty dollars for his Harvard tuition; even twice the amount would have been a mere pittance.

placid.example: Doug is normally placid, so we were all shocked to see him yelling at the television when the Mets lost the game.

plodding.example: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultramarathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

ploy.example: Dennis arranged an elaborate ploy, involving 14 different people lying for him in different situations, so that it could appear that he was meeting Mary completely by chance at the wedding reception.
ploy.meaning: a clever plan to turn a situation to one's advantage

powwow.example: Before the team takes the field, the coach always calls for a powwow so that he can make sure all the players are mentally in the right place.

precarious.example: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

precedent.example: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.
precedent.meaning: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time

preempt.example: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.
preempt.meaning: take the place of or have precedence over

preemptive.example: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.
preemptive.meaning: done before someone else can do it

presumption.example: When Mr. Baker found out the family car was gone, he acted under the presumption that his rebellious son had taken the car, calling his son's phone and yelling at him; only later did Mr. Baker realize that Mrs. Baker had simply gone out to get her nails d
presumption.meaning: an assumption that is taken for granted

presumption.example: The new neighbor quickly gained a reptuation for her presumption; she had invited herself to several of the neighbors homes, often stopping over at inopportune times and asking for a drink.
presumption.meaning: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to

presumptuous.example: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

prevail.example: During the labor negotiations, an air of hostility prevailed in the office.
prevail.meaning: be widespread in a particular area at a particular time; be current:

prevail.example: Before the cricket match, Australia was heavily favored, but India prevailed.

pristine.example: The glacial lake was pristine and we filled our canteens to drink deeply.
Drill sergeants are known for demanding pristine cabinets, uniforms, and beds, and often make new recruits clean and clean and clean until they meet the expected high standards.

profuse.example: During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts. Note:

profusion.example: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.
profusion.meaning: the property of being extremely abundant

proponent.example: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.
proponent.meaning: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea

provisional.example: Until the corporate office hands down a definitive decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.
provisional.meaning: under terms not final or fully worked out or agreed upon

pugnacious.example: The comedian told one flat joke after another, and when the audience started booing, he pugnaciously back at them, "Hey, you think this is easy -- why don"t you buffoons give it a shot?"
pugnacious.meaning: eager to fight or argue; verbally combative

qualm.example: While he could articulate no clear reason why Harkner's plan would fail, he neverless felt qualms about committing any resources to it.
qualm.meaning: uneasiness about the fitness of an action

quandary.example: unfavorable options Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.
quandary.meaning: state of uncertainty or perplexity especially as requiring a choice between equally

quip.example: In one of the most famous quips about classical music, Mark Twain said: "Wagner's music is better than it sounds."

raffish.example: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.
raffish.meaning: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness

raft.example: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.
raft.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

rakish.example: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.
rakish.meaning: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness

rankle.example: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.
rankle.meaning: gnaw into; make resentful or angry

rash.example: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nightime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.
rash.meaning: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences; imprudently incurring risk
rash.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

redress.example: Barry forgot his wife's birthday two years in a row, and was only able to redress his oversight by surprising his wife with a trip to Tahiti.
redress.meaning: an act of making something right
redress.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

relegate.example: When Dexter was unable to fulfill his basic duties, instead of firing him, the boss relegated him to kitchen cleanup.

remiss.example: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principle was relieved of his position after only three months.
remiss.meaning: to be negligent in one"s duty

renege.example: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.
renege.meaning: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation

replete.example: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.
replete.meaning: completely stocked or furnished with something

reprobate.example: Those old reprobates drinking all day down by the river--they are not going to amount to much.
reprobate.meaning: a person who is disapproved of

reservation.example: I was initially excited by the idea of a trip to Washington, D.C. but now that I have read about the high crime statistics there, I have some reservations.
reservation.meaning: an unstated doubt that prevents you from accepting something wholeheartedly
reservation.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resignation.example: Since Jack could not think of a convincing reason why he had to miss the seminar, he attended it with a sense of resignation.
resignation.meaning: the acceptance of something unpleasant that can't be avoided
resignation.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resolve.example: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.
resolve.meaning: reach a conclusion after a discussion or deliberation
resolve.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

respite.example: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.
respite.meaning: a pause from doing something (as work)

retiring.example: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees--rather than mill about with "fashionable" folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.
retiring.meaning: to be shy, and to be inclined to retract from company

retract.example: under pressure Email is wonderfully efficient, but once something awkward or damaging has been sent, there is no way to retract it.
retract.meaning: pull inward or towards a center; formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief, usually

rile.example: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.
rile.meaning: cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations

robust.example: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.
robust.meaning: sturdy and strong in form, constitution, or construction

sanctimonious.example: Even during the quiet sanctity of evening prayer, she held her chin high, a sanctimonious sneer forming on her face as she eyed those who were attending church for the first time.
sanctimonious.meaning: making a show of being pious; holier-than-thou

sanguine.example: With the prospect of having to learn 3,000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.

savvy.example: Although a great CEO, he did not have the political savvy to win the election.
The student savvies the meaning of astrophysics with little effort.
With his savvy business partner, the company was able to turn a profit within a year.

scintillating.example: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures--the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.
scintillating.meaning: describes someone who is brilliant and lively

screed.example: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government's deficiencies--only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big business.

sentimental.example: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas--overly sentimental.
sentimental.meaning: effusively or insincerely emotional, especially in art, music, and literature

serendipity.example: The invention of the 3M Post It Note was serendipitous, because the scientist who had come up with the idea was looking for a strong adhesive; the weak adhesive he came up with was perfect for holding a piece of paper in place but made it very easy for so
serendipity.meaning: the instance in which an accidental, fortunate discovery is made

serene.example: I'd never seen him so serene; usually, he was a knot of stress and anxiety from hours of trading on the stock exchange.

slapdash.example: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the facade of the building.

smattering.example: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.
smattering.meaning: a slight or superficial understanding of a subject; a small amount of something

smug.example: When Phil was dating the model, he had a smug attitude that annoyed his buddies.
smug.meaning: marked by excessive complacency or self-satisfaction

snide.example: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.
snide.meaning: expressive of contempt; derogatory or mocking in an indirect way

snub.example: Wheeler was completely qualified for the committee, but the board snubbed him, choosing an obviously lesser qualified candidate instead.
snub.meaning: refuse to acknowledge; reject outright and bluntly

sordid.example: and run-down and repulsive The nightly news simply announced that the senator had had an affair, but the tabloid published all the sordid details of the interaction.
sordid.meaning: involving ignoble actions and motives; arousing moral distaste and contempt; foul
sordid.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

spendthrift.example: Taking weekly trips to Vegas, Megan was a spendthrift whose excesses eventually caught up to her.

spurn.example: She spurned all his flattery and proposals, and so he walked off embarrassed and sad.

squander.example: Fearing his money would be squandered by his family, he gave all of it to charity when he died.
squander.meaning: spend thoughtlessly; waste time, money, or an opportunity

staid.example: Frank came from a staid enviroment, so he was shocked that his college rooommate sold narcotics.

start.example: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.
start.meaning: to suddenly move in a particular direction
start.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

steadfast.example: A good captain needs to be steadfast, continuing to hold the wheel and stay the course even during the most violent storm.
steadfast.meaning: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable

stem.example: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.
stem.meaning: to hold back or limit the flow or growth of something
stem.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

stipend.example: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

stolid.example: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.
stolid.meaning: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; not easily aroused or excited

stymie.example: The engineers found their plans stymied at every turn and were ultimately able to make amlost no progress on the project.
stymie.meaning: hinder or prevent the progress or accomplishment of

summit.example: After hiking for two days, the climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro.
Since climate change policy has been mired in congressional fighting, this summit should help set the goals for president's next term.

surly.example: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.
surly.meaning: inclined to anger or bad feelings with overtones of menace

tact.example: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelley more attractive than Marcia.
tact.meaning: consideration in dealing with others and avoiding giving offense

tarnish.example: Pete Rose was one of the best baseball players of his generation, but his involvement with gambling on baseball games has tarnished his image in the eyes of many.
tarnish.meaning: make dirty or spotty, as by exposure to air; also used metaphorically

tawdry.example: Carol expected to find New York City magical, the way so many movies had portrayed it, but she was surprised how often tawdry displays took the place of genuine elegance.

taxing.example: The hike to the summit of Mt. Whitney was so taxing that I could barely speak or stand up.
taxing.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

telling.example: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.
telling.meaning: significant and revealing of another factor

telltale.example: The many telltale signs of chronic smoking include yellow teeth, and a persistent, hacking cough.

tender.example: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.
tender.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

thoroughgoing.example: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.

thrifty.example: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

thwart.example: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.
thwart.meaning: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of

tirade.example: In terms of political change, a tirade oftentimes does little more than make the person speaking red in the face.

tout.example: At the conference, the CEO touted the extraordinary success of his company's Research & Development division.
tout.meaning: advertize in strongly positive terms; show off

transitory.example: If we lived forever and life was not transitory, do you think we would appreciate life less or more?

travail.example: While they experienced nothing but travails in refinishing the kitchen, they completed the master bedroom in less than a weekend.
travail.meaning: use of physical or mental energy; hard work; agony or anguish

tribulation.example: As of 2013, nearly 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country hoping to escape the tribulations of a civil war tearing their country to pieces.
tribulation.meaning: something, especially an event, that causes difficulty and suffering

tumult.example: Riots broke out just in front of our apartment building, and the tumult continued late into the night.
tumult.meaning: a state of chaos, noise and confusion

uncanny.example: normal Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.
uncanny.meaning: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences; surpassing the ordinary or

uncompromising.example: The relationship between Bart and Hilda ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising, never wanting to change their opinions.

unconscionable.example: The lawyer's demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

underwrite.example: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

unnerve.example: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly "Magoosh-ing", and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.

unprecedented.example: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.
unprecedented.meaning: having never been done or known before; novel

unruly.example: authority Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene--unless it's nap time.
unruly.meaning: (of persons) noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline; unwilling to submit to

unseemly.example: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.
unseemly.meaning: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society

urbane.example: experience Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophistcate spy James Bond.
urbane.meaning: showing a high degree of refinement and the assurance that comes from wide social

vacuous.example: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.
vacuous.meaning: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance

vanquish.example: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.
vanquish.meaning: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict

variance.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".

veneer.example: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.
veneer.meaning: covering consisting of a thin superficial layer that hides the underlying substance

vicarious.example: another The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can--through hundreds of intimate "tweets"--vicariously live the life of a famous person.
vicarious.meaning: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of

vie.example: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.

vindictive.example: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.
vindictive.meaning: to have a very strong desire for revenge

virago.example: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago's invective--she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

voracious.example: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.
voracious.meaning: very hungry; approaching an activity with gusto

wanton.example: appetites Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.
wanton.meaning: without check or limitation; showing no moral restraints to one's anger, desire, or

wax.example: Her enthusiasm for the diva's new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.
wax.meaning: to gradually increase in size or intensity
wax.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

whimsical.example: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.
whimsical.meaning: determined by impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
